intro: Sedastrum chapalense, commonly known as the Chapalense sedastrum, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly found in regions of Argentina and Chile. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows in grassy areas and is adapted to temperate climates with well-drained soils. Its foliage is usually lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are small and clustered in dense inflorescences. Sedastrum chapalense plays a role in local ecosystems by providing nectar for pollinators and serving as a food source for certain herbivorous insects.
